description.narrative: Protected areas system in Georgia expanded and strengthened via raising cost-effectiveness and capacities of PAs ad improved management practices.
nature reserve

Ensuring sufficiency and predictability of revenue sources for the PA system
US value of capitalization of sinking fund

comment.narrative: Technically speaking the value of the GEF Sinking Fund SFAF1 is still 1000000 since no additional donations to this particular sinking fund were made Meanwhile CNF has received significant donations outside the sinking fund To give a sense of the reality of the project CNF reports 4554000 taking into account GEF funding plus 13 of Euro 12 million funding from BMZ plus private donations We are therefore significantly above the target of 2435000 To December 2014 we spent 2 million in the PAs and plan a further 567095 in 2015 reaching our spending target of 2435000 In addition to this funding we have received a further EUR 5 million into the endowment putting us on target for a long term funding capacity of 800000 pa

description.narrative: Increase in tools PA system revenue generation

comment.narrative: An agreement in principle has been reached with the MoENRP for the relevance of introducing PA entry fees High level staff changes have hampered making further progress

description.narrative: Longterm annual funding capacity of CNF available for Georgia based on its endowment sinking fund and other regular annual commitments

comment.narrative:
950000 original target
800000 revised as agreed by the PEB following the MTR

CNF is on target to the agreed annual reduction of 800000 by project end
In 2014 CNF reduced the funding gap with 612000 for 2015 the projection is 567095

description.narrative: Reduce annual funding gap by 440000 by 2013

comment.narrative:
70 of basic funding
The baseline level in 2008 was actually 51 70 is the 2013 target with the sister project The 2013 target is 88 including the projected increase in government funding CNF was to add 440000 to this increased 2013 financing level
47 of optimal funding
See the comments above This includes the projected revenues from the sister project

94 of basic funding
Under the assumptions on the reduction of project targets discussed above CNF adds 800000 by project end and an additional 200000 are provided by a combination of increased government and tourism related funding following MTR the PEB adjusted this target is from 96 to 94 of basic funding and 625 of optimal funding

Financial scorecard at MTR assessed combined support from government and donors to cover 86 of basic funding or 58 of optimal funding
In 2014 CNF reduced the funding gap with 612000 for 2015 the projection is 567095
CNF is on target to the agreed annual reduction of 800000 by project end revised as agreed by the PEB following the MTR

description.narrative: Number of PAs financed from CNF

comment.narrative: CNF is currently not financing any PAs
Four to five PAs financed by 2013

In 2015 9 PAs are receiving support from CNF 6 PAs receive full operational support BKNP LPA VPA TPA MNP and JPA while 3 PAs Kazbegi Kintrishi and Algeti are receiving planning and infrastructure funding from KfW and basic operational support salaries topup and some smaller itemsfrom CNF

description.narrative: Raising costeffectiveness and capacities of PAs

Adoption of site specific business plans at 10 PAs providing transparency on the optimum level of management costs
The MTR recommended that this indicator be replaced by the following Technical assistance is in place for the preparation and the implementation of Operational Plans OPs by all the PAs covered by CNF

comment.narrative:
10 business plans adopted 10 PAs original target
Technical assistance has been provided and Operational Plans are in effect at all PAs covered by CNF 89 PAs in 2016 as revised by the PEB after the MTR
Operational plans OPs were developed and submitted by BKNP VPA and TPA In 2015 additionally OPs were prepared for JPA Kazbegi Algeti and Kintrishi PAs

description.narrative: Number of site managers trained in costeffective management

comment.narrative:
At least three in a minimum of 10 targeted PAs original target
An accounting system for PAs is in place and is adopted by all PAs target revised by the PEB after the MTR

Training in the use of the accounting system has been provided to 9 members of APAs central staff and PA staff in 2014
Additional training is planned for 2015 to staff of newly CNFsupported PAs

description.narrative:
Increase in costeffectiveness of at least 10 PAs measured by financial score card part II component II
The discussion at MTR indicate that the FSSC is not feasible at PAs level and cannot be used to assess the costefficiency of PAs The MTR suggested that this indicator be replaced by the following An accounting system is in place at APA and adopted that covers all PAs

comment.narrative:
008
Only a very basic accounting system exists

033
A modern and fully functional accounting system is in place original indicator
An accounting system is in place at APA and covers all PAs as revised by PEB after the MTR
An accounting system hardware and software has been established at APA and covers all PAs During the transitional year 2015 APA will upload balance sheet data

description.narrative: Existence of electronic system to track changes in management effectiveness based on the METT score and where appropriate on the Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative: No such system exists
Development and implementation of such a system

In 2014 an updated METT Scorecard was prepared for LPA in conjunction to a renewed grant agreement For JPA the baseline METT Scorecard was prepared
In 2015 updated METT Scorecards for renewed grant agreement will be prepared for TPA and VPA Baseline METT Scorecards will be prepared for Kazbegi Algeti and Kintrishi PAs

description.narrative: To secure longterm financial sustainability of the Georgian PA system
Area of sustainably financed PAs

comment.narrative:
At least 100000 ha cat III by 2013
400000 ha cat IIV by 2017 This target was reformulated following MTR as agreed by PEB
28645836 ha category IIV

description.narrative: Improved funding ratio of optimal needs of PAs measured by financial sustainability score card

comment.narrative:
047
The baseline level was 034 excluding the assumed increase in funding from revenues generated by the sister project see below

0625
The ratio of current financing to optimally required financing reached 058 at yearend 2013 according to Financial Scorecard at midterm review This figure takes the total revenues available to PAs and divides it by the optimal funding calculation at 2013 Following MTR the PEB agreed to adjust this target downwards from the original 07 for two reasons First the optimal funding foreseen in the Financial Scorecard increased compared to project outset which made it even more challenging to achieve the planned financing level A more fundamental reason to reduce the target however was that all assumed incremental funding sources are falling somewhat short of their planned additions to system revenues as described below The Project Documents Annex G assumed an improvement of 1114 million from the tourism and concession revenues generated as a result of the sister project 2013 revenues from tourism and concessions amounted to almost 650000 While not all tourism and concession revenues are actually attributable to the sister project for purposes of these calculations they are all attributed to the sister project Nevertheless it seems unlikely that tourism revenues will increase by the planned amount by 2017 An improvement of 1019 million was assumed from State funding So far while there has been a GEL increase in the budget no dollar increase has been achieved the GEL exchange rate weakened from 14GEL in 2008 to 168GEL in 2013 The 2008 baseline was 29 million in State funding for the PAsthe same amount as is shown in 2013 Finally CNFs own target at present is to reach 800000 per annum by 2017 an increase of 300000 from 2013 but still 150000 short of the planned 950000 annual contribution assumed from CNF in the project document If CNF funding can reach 800000 and tourism revenues or the state budget can increase by 200000 the revised 0625 target can be achieved

A quantitative assessment of the funding ratio will be completed for the TE in 2017
612000 disbursed by CNF in 2014 as such established annual target was factually reached
During 2015 CNF plans to disburse 567095 As of June 30 2015 CNF factually disbursed up to 286500 on track to meet the 2015 target Expressed in Euro CNFs main currency CNF support to PAs increases annually but due to the devaluation of the Euro against the the target for 2015 appears lower than planned
Government funding in 2014 increased in GEL by 318 compared to 2013 due to major investments in infrastructure

description.narrative: Critical ecosystems of protected areas providing habitats for endemic and endangered species are conserved

comment.narrative: Ecosytems are deteriorating
Habitats in 45 Cat III PAs are conserved by 2013

CNF currently supports 9 Cat IIV PAs including for better accountancy planning and patrolling
Data collected for 4 species as part of the established pilot biodiversity monitoring program in BKNP during 2014 are being analyzed
A replication biodiversity monitoring program is designed for implementation in Lagodekhi PA during 2015
